metadata.title: Will Streamlit cause the extinction of Flask? | by Bruce H. Cottman, Ph.D. | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Will Streamlit cause the extinction of Flask?
metadata.description: We have yet to encounter one of our Flask-based ML or DL micro-services that can not be refactored into a Streamlit service. The challenge is to keep Streamlit micro-services small by only replacing…

all_paragraphs: We have yet to encounter one of our Flask-based ML or DL micro-services that can not be refactored into a Streamlit service.
The challenge is to keep Streamlit micro-services small by only replacing only 2 to 3 Flask-based micro-services.

I have worked or consulted at over 20 companies, and I was lucky to work at two that are large, very forward-thinking, continually improving, and make innovation an integral part of their corporate strategy.
I work for a company whose management appreciates the rapid evolution of new open-source packages and lets me evaluate them for possible adoption.

Currently, I am refactoring Flask micro-services into Streamlit micro-services. These refactored prototypes, if proven better in maintenance expenses (and pass our test pyramid), are allowed to be put into production.
By replacing working Flask micro-services, we are violating the “not broke, do not fix “ catechism.
I consider the use of Streamlit to “ replace what is not broke” to be very forward-thinking and innovative (but then again, I am very biased). Time will tell if it is an improvement or not.
In an earlier post, I compared Flask to Streamlit using the simple hello World! example. We found that Flask needed seven lines of code while Streamlit needed two lines of code.

I put both micro-services in a Docker container whose environment was Python 3.7. I used Docker so that we could compare Flask to Streamlit, and my examples could be easily reproduced on your platform.
We found no difference in effort creating a Docker container for Flask or Streamlit. Either one can is used as a production micro-service on a local web service or your cloud provider.
Note: In this article, I did not use a production server, such as Heroku.
We will journey together, creating a more complicated micro-service than Hello-world!. Flask and Streamlitwill compare web-app implementations that have input, pandas dataframe display, and plotting.
We will use Docker again so that we can compare Flask to Streamlit, and examples can be easily reproduced on your platform.
When building websites, you should have a robust framework that can handle all types of features. One of the most popular micro-service frameworks among Python full-stack software engineers is Flask.
Think of Flask as a collection of software packages which can help you easily create a web application. These components can be assembled and further extended.
Streamlit is an open-source Python framework that enables us to develop and deploy web-based applications.
And Web frameworks are hard to learn. I still get confused in all that HTML, CSS, and Javascript with all the hit and trials, for something seemingly simple to do.

In this article, we will continue to find that we need to be a competent Python full-stack Flask software engineer. We will need to know how to use Javascript, HTML, CSS, WTForms, and/or Bootstrap and/or Flask-RESTful and/or (very, very many package opportunities).
I find Flask to be a robust framework. It is made more powerful by all the extensions. More importantly, it accommodates your style of programming by offering package extensions that suit you.

A good full-stack Flask programmer will have years of experience. However, an excellent Streamlit hacker (like a Machine Learning Scientist) requires weeks of experience to design, develop, and deploy a production-ready web-based dashboard.

If we are Python Streamlit Machine Learning or Deep Learning Scientists, we do NOT need to know Javascript, HTML, CSS, etc.., and different POST/GET URL packages in the stack. Instead, our software stack consists of Streamlit (and maybe Docker). That is it!

The result was specialization. Front end developers handled the HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Back end developers handled the host operating system, the HTTP server, and the database. And developers that were fluent in both were termed full stack developers.

Specialization was a good thing. Until it wasn’t. On the one hand, it meant that teams could work in parallel to shorten the development cycle. On the other hand, it meant we had to work extra hard to communicate initial requirements and change-order specifications, or we’d risk losing the benefit of that parallel work effort.
So having a team of full stack developers, without distinguishable front end/back end groups, seemed like a good idea.
Accomplish the following in a directory of your choosing:

In another blog, we created the/webAppsdirectory tree with all the code. Use git clonein a different parent directory different than last time, to get updates (or use the same parent directory and overwrite any changes you made to original code. Or… I will let you decide how you want to manage your filesystem.
For our first implementation of a Flask micro-service I will display a Pandas dataframe.

The datasetargument from the browser URL gets returned and assigned to dataset_namein dataviewer1.py running on the server. This is very basic variable setting in the server code (i.e. http://localhost:5000/show?dataset=Airq).

Thanks to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22180993/pandas-dataframe-display-on-a-webpage/22233851, I am saved from learning HTML and Bootstrap (after all, I am an impatient ML scientist). Bootstrap is one of the extensive array of extensions available with Flask.
Using our own HTML template we could customize the web page layout.
I will leave it to the reader to further customize with CSS or any Flask extension(s) that you may use.
I will use the wtform package to protect against cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks. We will be using WTForm app.config['SECRET_KEY']. The command in your console is:
I put the key generated at the top of my dataView-3.py file.
I have not out in @app.routeI. The result is:
I used Bokeh's zoom in the toolbar to zoom-in on lines in dataset. I create great interactive graphs with Bokeh and avoid using Javascript directly

In this implementation of dataViewer.py,I will use Streamlit. I don't really need to break this implementation into steps, as this dataViewer.py is just python, some Streamlit functions and the pandas package.
The Streamlit implementation required 10 statement lines of Python code which referenced the packages: streamlit, pandas, and pydataset.
The package pydataset contains over 750 datasets.
In your implementation, the dataset_ids(dataset names) sort in ascending alphabetical order in both the description box at top of display and the dropdown choicebox.
Notice how the choice box expands when you click on it.

The dataset you choose displays in the 3rd box from the top. A feature of Streamlit is that the presentation of the dataset is dynamic, and the values of each column sorts ascending or descending. Also, if the display box is not wide or high enough to display all columns or rows, then it becomes, it becomes scrollable in the horizontal or vertical axis.
In the last box, we see the line chart of the dataset. Each line corresponds to a numeric column (feature) of the dataset.

On the actual live implementation of this Streamlit micro-service ( as opposed to the static screenshot shown here), you can drag horizontally or vertically to change the horizontal or vertical scale. You can also zoom in and zoom out to change the size.

Beneath the covers of Streamlit is output on the chosen port of a web page of Javascript, HTML, CSS, JSON, and web communication to and fro. While I have given up some low-level control, I have gained a potent mechanism to transform python scripts into full-featured web applications.
In many ways, what we are comparing here is analogous to using a 4th generation high-level language (Streamlit) to machine assembler ( Flask, Javascript, HTML, CSS, JSON, post/get, etc.).
I will leave it as a programming exercise for you to extend this implementation to offer a choicebox for the selection of different charts.
The difference in Docker containers for Streamlit for dataViewer.py and HelloWorld.py are are the names of the containers and the entries inrequirements.txt.
If you get any of these messages, you need to start or restart Docker. I am on a Mac, so I just restart Docker Desktop.
You encounter this very obscure problem with Docker by running different containers on port:5000.
The fix is shown below and is typed in your terminal window. (I am sure there are better ones.)
step 2. Kill the process(es) which is/are currently using the port using its <PID>.

In this article, we compared Flask-based to Streamlit-based web applications using an example that had input, an interactive dataset display, and a line chart of the numeric columns of the dataset. We found that Flask needed approximately 100 lines of code while Streamlit needed ten lines of code.
We found to create the Flask micro-service we needed to know, at least, how to use HTML and CSS.

We can put both micro-services in a Docker container whose environment is a Python rc (release candidate). Either one can is used as a production micro-service on a local web service or your cloud provider.
In Part 3, we will develop together a more complicated micro-service that has a complete machine learning pipeline. In Part 3, we will avoid being a full-stack Flask developer by using Streamlit.
In a future article, I will compare Dash to Streamlit.

Dash Enterprise is Plotly’s commercial product for deploying Dash Apps on your company’s servers or on AWS, Google Cloud, or Azure. It offers an enterprise-wide Dash App Portal, easy git-based deployment, automatic URL namespacing, built-in SSL support, LDAP authentication, and more.

To be fair, Facebook et al. will not be able to use Streamlit (yet) for their public-facing website, however, as we will see in Part 3, as a Machine Learning Scientist, who spends most of his day coding with Python libraries, Streamlit offers a straightforward Python API.
I was able to design, code, test, deploy a Streamlit-based ML dashboard in 4 days. My CTO put it on his desktop. (OK, I did it at his request.) He likes it.
Our full-stack team requires about three weeks using Flask (a week more using Django) to put a new ML application in production.

Streamlit does not require you to learn several new paradigms and languages, such as HTML, CSS, JSON, and JavaScript. It does not need you to know what Flask extension to use. Should I use Bootstrap or WTForms or something else or a combo of them?
I have programmed in Flask for a couple of months. I now understand the vast extent of knowledge a full-stack programmer uses to put in production a Flask-based micro-service. I am in awe of them.

If you are a Streamlit hacker (like me), you need NOT know Javascript, HTML, CSS, JSON, and different POST/GET URL packages in the stack. Instead, your stack will consist of Streamlit (and maybe Docker). That is it!
I hope you have found this blog on Streamlit useful. I am looking forward to writing a future blog in this area, and I hope you are also!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
I write my blog utilizing decades of experience in investment, programming, and data science.
